node.title: When Did Spotify Wrapped Get So Chatty?
node.alt: For the text of this year’s Spotify Wrapped feature, the streaming music service leaned on internet slang and trending topics.
node.description: This year’s data dump from the streaming music service leaned heavily on contemporary buzzwords and slang — and inspired many, many memes.
node.content: ["\u201cIn 2021 you did what you had to do.\u201d", "\u201cYou always understood the assignment.\u201d", "\u201cYou deserve a playlist as long as your skincare routine.\u201d", "No, these phrases were not uttered by a TikTok star or a cool mom. Instead, they are idioms that appear in the annual data-driven marketing campaign known as Spotify Wrapped.", "The feature, which was released on Dec. 1, shows users of the streaming music service the songs and artists they listened to most throughout the year. Its arrival reliably inspires a number of screenshots and memes on social media. In 2020, for example, people posted about how fittingly depressing (or soothing) some of their most-listened-to tracks were.", "This time, much of the commentary revolved around the campaign\u2019s use of internet slang (\u201cliving rent-free in my head,\u201d \u201cvibe check,\u201d \u201cmain character\u201d) and its references to popular topics (NFTs, skin care regimens). In one meme, a Twitter user joked about personal finance using the tone of the Spotify campaign: \u201cYour checking account balance was in the bottom .003%. Weird flex but ok!\u201d", "Some users also noted surprising revelations about their listening habits. (Who knew they were in the top .05 percent of Doja Cat listeners?) Others found something resembling self-knowledge in the \u201caura\u201d readings that Spotify generated based on the moods suggested by their music tastes. (One person on Twitter jokingly reported that Spotify had deemed their audio aura as being \u201cfertile and breedable.\u201d)", "After the feature\u2019s Dec. 1 release, the hashtag #SpotifyWrapped trended for a couple of days, and the memes have been endless. In short, Spotify has collected a lot of data and is now reaping the benefits.", "Kelsey McGarry, 28, who lives in Los Angeles and works as a grant writer and coordinator for the city\u2019s homeless services, spent practically a whole day poring over her own Spotify Wrapped. She said that the results felt like an accurate read of who she is.", "\u201cMy Spotify Wrapped is very gay,\u201d said Ms. McGarry, who added that her top artist of the year was Charlie XCX. She enjoyed looking back at her year in music but noted that the language in this year\u2019s Wrapped was occasionally distracting.", "\u201cMy skin care routine isn\u2019t even long,\u201d Ms. McGarry said. \u201cLike, what are you talking about?\u201d", "Rajat Suresh, a 26-year-old comedian and writer, was one of the many people online who joked about Spotify leaning into playful language and buzzwords.", "\u201cIn 2021, you were not cancelled,\u201d Mr. Suresh wrote in a meme he posted on Twitter. \u201cBye Felicia! You got your Fauci Ouchie, and that\u2019s got the whole world shook.\u201d Along with the image, he added a question: \u201cWhy does Spotify talk like this?\u201d", "Ms. McGarry said that for her, those \u201ccringe\u201d moments, where the app seemed to be pulling phrases from a word cloud of popular slang and search terms, were a reminder that Spotify was a corporation and that sharing snippets from its Wrapped campaign on social media was \u201cfree advertising.\u201d", "According to Taj Alavi, the global head of marketing at Spotify, the company is always looking for new and creative ways to connect with Spotify listeners, of which there are more than 381 million worldwide.", "\u201cWe often lean into playful language and user experiences \u2014 it\u2019s a core part of who we are as a brand,\u201d Ms. Alavi wrote in an email. \u201cWhen we consider what the user experience will include, one of the most important factors is connecting with culture, not just making it all about Spotify. So you\u2019ll notice playful references to cultural trends from 2021 reflected in the interactive user experience.\u201d", "Mr. Suresh said that he uses Spotify a lot, making it \u201cone of the companies that knows everything\u201d about him. For him, though, this year\u2019s roundup reached a little too far.", "\u201cIt just felt like a classic Twitter thing of when the brand is trying to seem like a human or something,\u201d he said in a phone interview from his home in Brooklyn, noting that he\u2019d rather just see the data.", "That\u2019s not to say he didn\u2019t check his Spotify Wrapped with genuine curiosity. His top artist, he said, was Elliott Smith."]
